item.description: Shaobing Xu is an assistant research scientist (from 1/2019) and was a postdoctoral researcher (10/2016-12/2018) working with Prof. Huei Peng at the Department of Mechanical Engineering (ME) and Mcity, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. He received his Ph.D. degree in Mechanical Engineering from Tsinghua University, Beijing, China, in 2016. His work lies at learning, control, and design of autonomous systems with an emphasis on connected automated vehicles (CAVs). Appointment Assistant Research Scientist, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 1/2019-Now Postdoctoral Research Fellow, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, 10/2016-12/2018 Education Tsinghua University (9/2011-6/2016)
Email: xushao@umich.edu Address: 2905 Baxter Road, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-2150

Refer to Google Scholar May 1, 2020 Selected Journal Papers [J10] S. Xu, H. Peng, and Y. Tang, “Preview Path Tracking Control with Delay Compensation for Autonomous Vehicles,” IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems, 2020. [J9] S. Xu, H. Peng, P. Lu, M. Zhu, and Y. Tang, “Design and Experiments of Safeguard Protected Preview Lane Keeping Control for Autonomous Vehicles,” IEEE Access, vol. 8, pp. 29944-29953, 2020. doi: 10.1109/ACCESS.2020.2972329 [J8] S.

Overview My research targets safe autonomy against uncertainty and aims to build safe connected automated vehicles (CAVs). Over the past 5 years, I have been engaged in two lines of research, i.e., a scalable motion planning and control algorithm/software stack for high-level CAVs, and an AI-driven sensor-level augmented reality for efficient CAV tests. Some past projects are introduced below. 1. Intelligent Motion Planning This project aims to develop intelligent algorithms and software for automatic routing, decision making, and trajectory generation of self-driving vehicles.

item.title: Teaching
item.description: Teaching as Guest Lecturer ME599-Automated and Connected Vehicle, 3 lectures on the part of vehicle dynamics and motion control, Mar 2018
